channel.title: Lucas‚Äô Music
channel.description: Sometimes I make music, and occasionally I even record it. Don‚Äôt expect too much polish, though. In reverse chronological order (newest recordings first):

item.title: Fragments of a March (‚ÄúKatowice‚Äù)
item.description:
I wrote these ‚Äúfragments of a march‚Äù in January 2020, inspired by some other march music I had listened to (such as Unter dem Doppeladler, which ContraPoints used in some of her videos and I had previously transcribed an arrangement for, or the Entrance of the Gladiators). It seemed to me that these marches frequently had three distinct parts: a beginning with the whole band (‚ÄúA‚Äù), a middle part with the low brass instruments taking the lead (‚ÄúB‚Äù), and an end in a different key (‚ÄúC‚Äù); I had a ‚ÄúB‚Äù part and a ‚ÄúC‚Äù part in my head, and I wrote them down, but a matching ‚ÄúA‚Äù part never materialized. (These parts probably have real names in music theory ‚Äì a part of me wants to call the ‚ÄúC‚Äù part a ‚Äútrio‚Äù? ‚Äì but I don‚Äôt know and don‚Äôt really care enough to look it up.)

More recently, I attended Wikimania 2024 in Katowice (maybe I‚Äôll write a separate blog post for that later), where I was part of the WikiOrchestra; this inspired me to record some more music, and I figured that I might as well record these fragments of a march. Since there should be something to disambiguate them from any other march-like music I might record in future, I am dedicating them to Katowice. (Naming marches after geographic places feels like a reasonable thing to do; compare, say, the Florentiner Marsch.)

In terms of the composition, I like the ‚ÄúB‚Äù part well enough, and I‚Äôm quite happy with the ‚ÄúC‚Äù part: I enjoy the way the melody and chords are mixing in the right hand. The accelerando in the bridge between them is a bit annoying, but I can‚Äôt really help it: to my ear, the ‚ÄúC‚Äù part needs to be rather faster than the ‚ÄúB‚Äù part, so we have to get from one to the other somehow ‚Äì unless I eventually write more march parts and can graft these two parts onto other bits with matching tempo. (I actually found a fragment of an alternative ‚ÄúC‚Äù part in the LilyPond score I had written back in 2020 when I came back to this now, but the ‚ÄúB‚Äù and ‚ÄúC‚Äù part recorded here is what has stuck in my head over the past four years, so that‚Äôs what I recorded.)

In terms of the notation of the composition (the PDF / LilyPond below)‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs really not great, but I don‚Äôt want to spend too much time perfecting it either. I have no idea if the time signature makes sense, or if this should be (say) 2/2 time instead of 4/4 time ‚Äì this is something that I never pay much attention to when reading a score, but find surprisingly difficult to figure out when writing one. But hey, it‚Äôs better than nothing.

The performance isn‚Äôt flawless, but it‚Äôs good enough ‚Äì if I tried to perfect every recording I upload, I would never upload anything, so I‚Äôm trying to be less obsessive about that. A few missed notes are annoying, but I think you can imagine what they‚Äôre supposed to be; the other major flaw is the tempo: even though I had already slowed down compared to some earlier test recordings, listening back to it I now think I was still too fast in the ‚ÄúC‚Äù part (and didn‚Äôt even hold a consistent tempo either). In my defense, the accelerando in the bridge makes it impossible to play with a metronome üòÖ

Download links

  • FLAC
  • MP3
  • WAV
  • PDF (score)
  • LilyPond (score)

item.title: Intermezzo in E‚ô≠ major
item.description:
For the Wikipaka assembly at rC3, I made a recording of the Intermezzo Nr. 1, the first of Johannes Brahms‚Äô Drei Intermezzi. It‚Äôs not perfect, but good enough that I thought I‚Äôd upload it here.

Download links

  • FLAC
  • MP3
  • WAV

Alternate version

I made two recordings. The one above is the first one, which I think has slightly more minor blunders but no larger problems; the following one worked better overall, but I made a larger mistake at the beginning of the ‚Äúthird‚Äù part, which is why I‚Äôm relegating it to the ‚Äúalternate‚Äù version. (I sent that version to Wikipaka, though, since I thought it overall sounded better and the mistake wasn‚Äôt so important in that context.)

item.title: Improvisation in e minor
item.description:
Just an odd idea I had one Friday night. Contains traces of Megalovania and the James Bond Theme.

item.title: Elite Syncopations Part A
item.description:
Between last and this week, two WMDE colleagues and I created a short film about the new Musical Notation data type on Wikidata. For some of the scenes, we needed recordings of Scott Joplin‚Äôs Elite Syncopations, so I sat down and played the A part on repeat until I thought there was enough usable snippets, and we were able to cut together something we could put in the video.

Download links

  • FLAC
  • MP3
  • WAV

Garbage

Another scene also called for a kind of distressed jangling, which would be played by the musician unable to read the LilyPond notation; I just improvised that for a while, first at random and then trying to guess what a musician might actually try to read from the text (most of the pitch names should be understandable if you‚Äôre familiar with Dutch/German note names, except for the q, which means ‚Äúrepeat chord‚Äù, but the notation to group several notes into a chord would not be easy to guess and might instead be played sequentially, etc.). And then I did that again because during the first improvisation I forgot to switch the piano to the same voice as for the proper recording.

item.title: Wikidata Rhythmic Improvisations
item.description:
The Wikidata logo consists mainly of a barcode spelling out the word WIKI in Morse:

I was wondering if you could convert that into some musical rhythm, and it turns out that if you take each wide bar as a quarter note, each thin bar as an eighth note, and each gap as an eighth rest, you end up with a rhythm that‚Äôs twelve quarter notes long ‚Äì

‚Äì and distributes quite nicely across either three 4/4-time bars ‚Äì

‚Äì or two 6/4-time bars, which in my opinion makes more sense both musically and when looking at the logo image:

(The source code for all three images is wikidata.ly.)

It‚Äôs not a full composition, and I haven‚Äôt really internalized the rhythm yet, but still I think it‚Äôs rather pretty, and a bit catchy. The recording above is just what I made of it, but you could obviously apply this rhythm it a lot of different ways.

(I have to admit that my interpretation, specifically the C-D-G-C chord I used at the beginning and end, is influenced a bit by The First Circle, because I‚Äôll be honest ‚Äì I don‚Äôt know too many compositions that aren‚Äôt in 4/4 or 3/4 time. That‚Äôs probably also why I dropped a note and lapsed into 5/4 time a few times ‚Äì sorry.)

Download links

  • FLAC
  • MP3
  • WAV

item.title: Melody in C major
item.description:
A short melody in C major that I wrote. I only really found the first three bars, the rest is kinda fumbled together on autopilot to arrive at a properly closed piece.

I did have one ‚Äúepiphany‚Äù while practicing this, though ‚Äì notice how the melody dips down a few times? The left hand accompaniment and the right hand melody actually use the same keys here, and I was struggling at first with the melody being lost in the accompaniment ‚Äì but then I found that if I put some more emphasis on the melody and made the accompaniment a bit quieter, they‚Äôre quite well distinguishable. I‚Äôm sure my piano teachers tried to teach me this in the past, but perhaps I‚Äôll manage to internalize it better this time ‚ò∫

(I think this is an original composition, but I can‚Äôt deny a certain similarity to Ella Fitzgerald‚Äôs A Kiss Goodnight‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs possible that it was in the back of my head, or something.)

Download links

  • FLAC
  • MP3
  • WAV

item.title: B‚ô≠7/13 chord
item.description:
I found this really pleasing arrangement of a B‚ô≠7/13 chord while tinkering around on the piano, and I thought I should record it. (Includes a resolution to E‚ô≠ because I‚Äôm not a monster.)

item.title: Tango (Improvisation)
item.description:
(TL;DR: the recording gets more interesting after 0:35.)

My friend Merle lent me some of her piano training books, and in The European Piano Method (Volume 2) by Fritz Emonts I found this Tango, where you‚Äôre supposed to complete the accompaniment yourself. I took a bit more liberty ‚ò∫

The recording starts out with me just playing what‚Äôs in the actual sheet music, which isn‚Äôt very much. The second time round I play what I imagine they expect you to play, more or less. After that, I went a bit off track, and improvised ‚Äì mainly on the ‚Äútango‚Äù topic, but you‚Äôll hear some deviations, and you might even recognize some entirely different compositions in there.

Download links

  • FLAC
  • MP3
  • WAV

item.title: Happy Birthday Dear Wikidata
item.description:
I recorded three takes of improvisation / fantasy on Happy Birthday to You, dedicated to Wikidata for its fifth birthday. Above is my favorite version (take 5), below are the two other ones (take 4 and 2). (I also played two more takes, 1 and 3, but the recordings are lost due to computers.)

Each recording starts with just a reference note and then one full iteration of the melody, set in a fairly simple style ‚Äì if you want, you can play just that part and sing along to it. After that comes the improvisation, which isn‚Äôt really intended to be sung.

Note that while Happy Birthday to You is in the Public Domain, the improvisation includes snippets from other, non-PD compositions, just for the fun of it. I hope I kept them all short enough to not violate copyright (and God do I hate having to think about this while I‚Äôm playing; current copyright law is trash y‚Äôall), but you might want to consider that if you want to play these pieces publicly.

Download links

  • FLAC
  • MP3
  • WAV

Take 4

Take 2
